I'm new to the forums and I can be both liberal and conservative depending on the issue (pro death penalty, but pro choice for example).
 
 Basically there's really only one thing I can pick at pro-life people, because they have some good arguments definitely. And in all abortion debates I participate in, I refuse to debate when a baby is alive or if the baby has rights or any of that stuff that's ridicously open to intrepretation based on the individual. The one thing that bothers me however is pro life advocate's innate sense of self-righteousness. If you're pro life, you believe that people getting abortions are obviously murdering babies. That belief can be reasonably justified I suppose, but the fact of the matter is, it's not you that's getting an abortion. So let a girl (and perhaps with support from her boyfriend) go get an abortion and soil her/their hands with "murder" and let them be damned to hell or whatever. 
 Pro life people appear to be afraid either that someone they aren't being "good" and letting babies be killed or they are somehow better than everyone else and have the right to interject and "save" the "lives" of babies. On a personal level, go slap happy advising your friends not to get an abortion because you think it's bad. That's ok, why? Because you care about your friends and your friends' unborn kids. But the second you start wanting amendments/laws dictating for the entire nation, you are now essentially just looking down at complete strangers and playing Jesus or some other savior, in an effort to make yourself feel better that you did something "good" and "right." And you know what, perhaps you guys are right, and abortions are awful in the eyes of God or some other code of ethics, but I would rather kill a kid before she/he is anywhere close to consciousness than let them suffer a life of poverty, abuse and general despair (this is assuming obviously poor, unchangeable conditions, which isn't always the case for everyone pondering an abortion, I realize that), even if it means I hurt my own reputation/karma, because I just don't want my kid to suffer like that.
 As to the argument about killing potential future talented people, that's a rather illogically cynical view of humankind. Perhaps the abortion that my friend just got ended the life of a modern day Beethoven, but that's not to say there is absolutely no chance of a modern day Beethoven being born by someone else, somewhere else. That's like saying since that one baby who hasn't even been born yet, much less decided on a career path, was, is and will be the only one ever in all of eternity who could be a modern day Beethoven. It doesn't bother her because it wouldn't make sense to be bothered. That's like getting a glance at some person once at a party, then going home and crying because you missed out on the love of your life. Even if an all seeing entity knows that person is the one, you as a person do not since you never even talked to them and got to know them.

Oh and to answer the topic question, yes I do really care about human life. I'd be heart broken if my friends, co-workers, classmates, siblings, my parents, etc. (basically all the people I know) died. I wouldn't be care however if the "life" of the "baby" of some girl getting an abortion in Oklahoma died (I live in CT by the way). And I refuse to pretend that I do in an effort to appear caring (even though I easily could since this is just an online text message devoid of seeing my facial expression or tone when I say things). Also, if you consider this attitude selfish, it doesn't matter to me because this system of caring about the people you know and that's it actually works to maintain a healthy society because everyone has people they want to look out for. It's not like your friend who I don't know needs me to care about her potential abortion or not, it's you who needs to advise her (if you so choose to advise her at all).
